body:
I found two additional issues regarding IE in conjunction with google docs as datasource. 
1. Cross-Site requests must be targeted to the same schema which means that https xs-requests give an access denied error when called from an http site. See [this post on Microsoft blogs](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/05/13/xdomainrequest-restrictions-limitations-and-workarounds.aspx). I changed that to a [protocol relative url](http://paulirish.com/2010/the-protocol-relative-url/) 
2. as there is no built in support XDomainRequest, I added support for it. I need to check [this approach](https://github.com/jaubourg/ajaxHooks/blob/master/src/ajax/xdr.js) which would be far more elegant

I'll consider merging this back in. I didn't include it because I was following Times style and because the initial point on the timeline you come to is the start date. I'll take another look at including an end date in the title but I want to handle it with a different style to maintain emphasis on the start date.

The problem only surfaced in IE9. The URL needs to be on the same scheme as the calling page, therefore http for a http page, https for an https page. This is why I chose @paulirish's approach of the [protocol relative urls](http://paulirish.com/2010/the-protocol-relative-url/).

Sadly I found out later that protocol relative urls seem to either break `jQuery.ajax` calls or there's some issues in Chrome's handling of it all. that's why I needed to re-add the https scheme to the `VMM.getJSON` call.
Yes please!  I tested out the pull request and it works well for me.
Sorry, I messed this up. Didn't realize it'd pull subsequent commits and I pushed some test code into my repo. I'll make a branch and send another pull request.

it makes sense to me for Timeline should get out of the business of loading JSON files & _just_ take a JSON object. You could just give example code in the doc for how to load json from a file.
@gregwebs, that's probably safer, yeah. Glad it's working for you.

hi guys! I like how this is going with the user modifying a configuration for their own language. I am wondering if it is necessary at all to have date parsing be internal to this library. Rather than expecting the user to give a string, why not expect only a date object? Otherwise the user can register a string -> Date function. Certainly the library could keep a very simple date parser on hand.

Making a free-format string out of the date object would make many tasks performed automatically (generating the helper timeline at the bottom, calculating an interval that makes sense, sort the stuff by date when the editors are too lazy) almost impossible. 

This whole setup stuff for a language is a thing that in most cases needs to be done just once and then just copied over when inserting a new timeline.
This code only jumps to the correct marker. I am updating the code to jump to the correct marker and slide. I will resubmit the pull request when I am finished.

@mwidmann, I didn't read the code correclty. I am advocating only using a date object internally. Users are expected to give date objects or provide a date parsing function. But your patch is actually for the printing of dates and seems appropriate.
Working great with JSON obj! Thanks!

I'm not exactly clear on what this is supposed to fix.
I'm also worried that it will affect the min, max-width etc styles on elements according to http://css-tricks.com/box-sizing/

> Box-sizing should and does work with min-width / max-width / min-height / max-height with one exception:
> Firefox.
> and 
> http://www.quirksmode.org/css/box.html

I'm seeing issues in the latest version of Chrome if box-sizing isn't set on content-box. To give a specific example, I use border-box as the default setting in my theme and see the visual issues in this screenshot:

![box-sizing-visual](http://img256.imageshack.us/img256/8165/4fa94c1dd535cf2f0f00000.png)

As you can see, the toolbar looks wrong without content-box explicitly set and the media sizing in the timeline also is slightly off.

Tested in Chrome 18, FF12 and IE9 on Windows 7.
Since box sizing isn't widely used yet and can cause problems in firefox, shouldn't this be a specific fix for your use case?

Content-box is the default value for the box-sizing property, so this is akin to a reset. It shouldn't cause any problems in Firefox or any other standards-complaint browser.

Could I add this to my CSS file manually? Sure. But it's one extra line of code that won't break anything else and helps ensure rendering consistency.

It would appear that the package is already registered. It's not really clear to me how that could work without the bower.json file having existed, but those of you who are concerned with this issue should advise if there's actually more to do.

I didn't know of this is working without a bower.json file...
And it's look like some of your users didn't waited for an official support of Bower ;-)

Already [registered package](http://bower.io/search/?q=Timeline) are:
- **timelinejs**: https://github.com/StrictlySkyler/TimelineJS by @StrictlySkyler
- **timeline**: https://github.com/blesh/TimelineJS-Bower by @blesh

And there is two packages name that is pointing on the current repo:
- **NUKnightLab-TimelineJS** https://github.com/NUKnightLab/TimelineJS
- **timeline.js**: https://github.com/NUKnightLab/TimelineJS

If any, there is a procedure to unregister a bower package (see bower/bower#120).

The best way to solve this is to add documentation about how to install TimelineJS with Bower.

To be quite honest, we don't use Bower. If the community wants it, I'm happy to do the minor administration of integrating details, but I don't expect to add that documentation unless it comes in the form of a pull request.

I'd like to point out that you can register it with any other name that doesn't exist like TimelineJS-Official. It's a very used script and people wanted it early on bower so that happened. As people come across this is already in bower, the other versions will cease to exist naturally.

I hope it helps.
Hello, im trying to use this but in the timeline, two items with a diference of minutes or seconds is showed at same position, is not possible show it with the separation of the seconds?

We made this adjustment because it made the dates more consistent, instead of showing the year and day as number, but month as a chinese character.
An alternative approach is to translate the year and day to chinese characters, which is probably more difficult.

The fix in facd6fa7db1ea7f88e517f93dc564cbcfea95aa6 means that the scrollTop animation in `VMM.Slider.js` was never actually called and this didn't seem to matter:

https://github.com/NUKnightLab/TimelineJS/blob/b56fdcb28f01ebba24b0584db7a465772bd2d6dc/source/js/Core/Slider/VMM.Slider.js#L693

There should probably be some review of that entire block of code to see whether it's still relevant: the scroll_height declaration in the catch block appears to be completely redundant:

https://github.com/NUKnightLab/TimelineJS/blob/b56fdcb28f01ebba24b0584db7a465772bd2d6dc/source/js/Core/Slider/VMM.Slider.js#L697

+1 but aren't the months like `jannewaris` and `febrewaris` etc. ?  
http://taal.phileon.nl/fry_maanden.php
That depends, the `foarmanne` is considered more elegant and classical, while `jannewaris` is more general. I would say it is a matter of taste.

It looks like it's all part of trying to negotiate mixed-content pages. I'm a little nervous about taking it out, but then again, it seems arbitrary, and apparently in some cases just wrong. More to the point, it seems presumptuous for the library to do this. If it matters, people providing the URL should be responsible.

Thanks!

Interesting. The referenced page labels months like `foarmanne` with the word `Bijnaam`, which translates as nickname. In English, nicknames are the opposite of "elegant and classical".

This points up a challenge we have with accepting contributions for translation files for languages we don't speak. Any ideas for other sources we could check for priority, rather than having this be a matter of taste?

Technically, we could also support both, simply by having different menu choices, like "Frisian (bijnaam)" and "Frisian (???)" if we can come up with clear labels. Then the files would be "fy_bijnaam.js" and whatever is appropriate to the other form.

Yeah, the library rewriting URLs is unexpected.

When might we be able to expect a release, accessible via your CDN, of this change and the related image URL rewriting change at eea88334dd00df8ce8dbe77af66bff1b9a421455 ?

Thanks so much for Timeline.js !

Hi Joe,
When will the next release will be that incorporates these changes?

We need to know so that we can decide if we are going to host our own forked version (plus integration work) or just continue to point to Knight Lab CDN.

Thanks
These files aren't actually ever used, but until we strip them out of the CSS, we may as well accept your PR. Thanks!

Hi @JoeGermuska ,
This change does not break our implementation. However, conditionally rewriting URLs is unexpected behavior.

It is not the responsibility of the Timeline component to modify URLs - it should be the responsibility of those implementing the component to host and configure it appropriately to meet their use cases.

For example, what if the site including the Timeline was insecure, but must load data from an HTTPS source? It should just take the URL verbatim. Implementors could potentially feed it protocol-less URLs if they need to do so.

Perhaps a version bump is needed, given this change affects some implementors, who could then pin to an older version?

@defbyte You may be right, but (a) backwards compatibility is a higher priority for us and (b) in this case, it is to do with MSIE (a non-trivial component of our audience) reading Google Spreadsheets, which is fundamental to TImelineJS working.  So "shoulds" aside, we have to go with what works for the sizeable majority of our user base.

But yes, there would be a version bump with any adjustment to the code.
TimelineJS 2.34.1 has been released. If you want to pin to 2.34.0 it is at http://cdn.knightlab.com/libs/timeline/2.34.0/js/timeline-min.js
thank you!

There don't seem to be any problems embedding YouTube URLs in any of our test cases. Can you provide the value you entered for the media URL?

for instance, I just used [this YouTube URL](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UJcFp2d_TaM) on timeline.knightlab.com and got the expected behavior without your patch.

Sorry for the delay. I had a small crisis of confidence in accepting language patch requests considering I don't speak most of the languages... but then I figured I would just rely on Google Translate to sanity check.

https://developers.google.com/youtube/player_parameters#color

Or I can submit a new pull reuqest tomorrow.
@JoeGermuska  I heard there is a new default (official) standard and spell checker for frisian, but I currently don't own it. Maybe @Fokko has it?

I still believe that the patch will add value to the repository of languages. I have updated the naming of the months to the more popular variation as suggested by @spidfire. In both cases it is correct Frisian, but it is more a matter of taste.
Unfortunately I used the "fixed" code on an internal-facing project at my last job, so I no longer have access to my original example. I'll see if I can come up with another one.
Thank you.

Not sure if you prefer for pull requests to include built files or not; my build environment won't contain CDN stuff that you might need.  This PR does not include built files, so `built` will be out-of-sync with `source`.

Also: a simpler alternative to this PR would be to just use https: capable URLs always, rather than branching based on `document.location.protocol`.  If you prefer that strategy I'm happy to update the PR to use it.
I ended up opting for your simpler strategy. Thanks for the contribution.

Thanks, but the current usage adheres to AP style, and merging your change would retroactively change previously created timelines. Since there hasn't been discussion I've seen, it doesn't seem worth changing in the core. If we need to improve the docs on how to override the style with your own preferences, let us know.
Thank you.

I think in line 25 of all `en` locales (and spread in es locales at least) are missing a single quote char. In `en.js` you can see `'
` in line 25: ``` javascript full_long_small_date: "h:MM TT'
mmm d',' yyyy''" ``` **It should not be `'
'` instead, to end string quote?**: ``` javascript full_long_small_date: "h:MM TT'
'mmm d',' yyyy''" ``` Like in the line 23, that is enclosed: ``` javascript time_no_seconds_small_date: "h:MM TT'
'mmmm d',' yyyy''", ```
thank you

This code change was actually made in the wrong repository. TimelineJS3 is the current project repository. Please refer to the relevant PR in that repository: https://github.com/NUKnightLab/TimelineJS3/pull/413
